evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief
evidence.text: Plaintiff Jane Doe is a 21‑year‑old transgender woman who has been diagnosed with gender dysphoria

extracted.value: Jane Doe is a 21‑year‑old transgender woman diagnosed with gender dysphoria.

evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief
evidence.text: Jane’s father, Plaintiff John Doe, retired from the U.S. military as a Senior Master Sergeant after more than 23 years of honorable service in both the Marine Corps and Air Force.

extracted.value: Jane Doe is a dependent of her father John Doe, a retired Senior Master Sergeant with more than 23 years of service in the Marine Corps and Air Force.

evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief
evidence.text: Jane is a 21‑year‑old transgender woman who is entitled to receive healthcare benefits through the military’s TRICARE Health Plan (“TRICARE”), by virtue of being an eligible dependent of her father, Plaintiff John Doe.

extracted.value: Jane is eligible for TRICARE benefits under the military’s healthcare plan as a dependent of her father.

evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief
evidence.text: Jane has been denied critical treatments recommended by her doctors solely because of a federal statute dating to 1976, 10 U.S.C. § 1079(a)(11), that mandates the categorical exclusion of all surgical treatments for gender transition in the military’s medical coverage for eligible dependents of servicemembers.

extracted.value: Jane was denied critical treatments recommended by her doctors because of the federal statute 10 U.S.C. § 1079(a)(11).

evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief
evidence.text: Jane was referred to an endocrinologist for this treatment and began her prescribed medication of testosterone blockers and estrogen in 2018.

extracted.value: Jane began hormone replacement therapy (testosterone blockers and estrogen) in 2018.

evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief
evidence.text: In 2018 and 2019, upon the recommendation of her doctors, Jane sought coverage for medically necessary laser hair removal and electrolysis to eliminate visible male facial hair. ... Jane subsequently sought reimbursement from TRICARE for these costs, but TRICARE denied her claim and her subsequent appeals.

extracted.value: Coverage for laser hair removal and electrolysis was denied; Jane paid out‑of‑pocket and later sought reimbursement, which was denied.

evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief
evidence.text: In 2019 and 2021, Jane underwent facial feminization and voice feminization surgeries recommended by her doctors for her gender transition. These surgeries ... Instead, she procured alternative health insurance through her university at her own expense.

extracted.value: Jane underwent facial feminization and voice feminization surgeries in 2019 and 2021, which were paid for with alternative insurance and not covered by TRICARE.

evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief
evidence.text: In 2021, Jane’s doctors determined that a vaginoplasty is medically necessary surgical treatment for her gender dysphoria. ... Defendants denied authorization for even a consultation for this gender‑transition surgery based solely on the categorical exclusion in Section 1079.

extracted.value: Jane had a vaginoplasty in 2021; TRICARE denied authorization for the procedure and for a consultation.

evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief
evidence.text: Section 1079(a)(11) contains a categorical exclusion of all surgeries for the treatments for gender dysphoria.

extracted.value: Section 1079 contains a categorical exclusion of all surgeries for gender dysphoria for eligible dependents of servicemembers.

evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief
evidence.text: TRICARE Policy Manual 6010.60‑M (“Policy Manual”) states that ... surgical treatment of gender dysphoria for non‑active‑duty beneficiaries is prohibited by statute (10 USC 1079).

extracted.value: TRICARE Policy Manual 6010.60‑M excludes surgeries for gender dysphoria for non‑active‑duty beneficiaries.
